cards.title: Athletics / Ron Clarke, Australian world champion distance runner, dies at 78
cards.rawTitle: Ron Clarke, Australian world champion distance runner, dies at 78

item.title: Ron Clarke, Australian world champion distance runner, dies at 78
item.trailText: One of Australia’s greatest middle and distance runners and former Gold Coast mayor had been in poor health recently
item.standFirst: One of Australia’s greatest middle and distance runners and former Gold Coast mayor had been in poor health recently
item.body:
World champion runner and former Gold Coast mayor Ron Clarke has died at the age of 78.

Gold Coast city council confirmed Clarke’s death early on Wednesday. The man who rose to become one of Australia’s greatest middle and distance runners had recently been in poor health.

Clarke gained prominence on the athletics track in the 1950s and 1960s and officially set 17 world records.

After his athletics career ended, he served two terms as Gold Coast mayor from 2004, before making an unsuccessful bid for state politics.

In 1956, when Clarke was 19 and showing a lot of promise as a runner, he was chosen to light the flame during the opening ceremony for the Melbourne Olympics.

For all of his achievements, Clarke is perhaps best remembered for stories of cruel luck and near misses.

At the 1968 Olympics in Mexico City, Clarke – untrained for the high altitude – came close to blacking out late in the 10,000m event having been challenging for the lead. Virtually unconscious, he staggered on to finish sixth.

It wasn’t until years later he discovered he had damaged his heart as a result, requiring open heart surgery and daily medication.

Clarke eventually got his hands on an Olympic gold medal but from an unlikely source: friend and idol Emil Zátopek.

Zátopek invited him to Czechoslovakia where, upon greeting him at Prague airport, he handed him a package containing his 1952 medal.

“Look after this, you deserve it,” Zatopek reportedly told him. It was the kind of sportsmanship that Clarke seemed to attract.

At the 1956 national championships at Olympic Park, Clarke tripped on the penultimate lap of the 1,500m final and was accidentally spiked in the arm and shoulder by rival John Landy.

“I stopped to see how he was and he got up and said ‘keep going’, which I did and I won the race,” Landy recalled on ABC Radio.

“He was an outstanding athlete, not only in the sense of when he made records, but he really did show to the world what was possible in endurance running.

“He set a standard not only for Australian athletes but for world athletes.”

Off the track, Clarke was a successful businessman, author and politician.

He was elected the mayor of the Gold Coast in 2004, defeating the incumbent, Gary Baildon, and held onto the role until his resignation in 2012.

In that time he helped the city secure the 2018 Commonwealth Games and in 2013 was appointed an Officer (AO) in the General Division in the Queen’s Birthday honours.

displayImages.credit: Dave Hunt/AAP
displayImages.altText: Ron clarke
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Dave Hunt/AAP

bodyImages.caption: Ron Clarke, holder of the junior mile record, carries the Olympic torch into the stadium during the opening ceremony of the 1956 Olympic games in Melbourne.  Photograph: Keystone/Getty Images
bodyImages.altText: Australian athlete Ron Clarke, holder of the junior mile record, carries the Olympic torch into the stadium during the opening ceremony of the 1956 Olympic games in Melbourne.
bodyImages.cleanCaption: Ron Clarke, holder of the junior mile record, carries the Olympic torch into the stadium during the opening ceremony of the 1956 Olympic games in Melbourne.

headerImage.caption: Ron Clarke lit the Olympic flame in Melbourne in 1956. Photograph: Dave Hunt/AAP
headerImage.cleanCaption: Ron Clarke lit the Olympic flame in Melbourne in 1956.

snap.title: Ron Clarke, Australian world champion distance runner, dies at 78

image.cleanCredit: Photograph: Dave Hunt/AAP

cards.title: Rugby league / State of Origin: Queensland to fire up following 'left field' Gallen attack
cards.rawTitle: State of Origin: Queensland to fire up following 'left field' Gallen attack

item.title: State of Origin: Queensland to fire up following 'left field' Gallen attack
item.trailText: Queensland assistant Michael Hagan says NSW skipper Paul Gallen’s “left field” criticism has put the Maroons on notice ahead of State of Origin II
item.standFirst: • Queensland lead series 1 - 0 ahead of State of Origin Game II at MCG
item.body:
Queensland assistant Michael Hagan says NSW skipper Paul Gallen’s "left field" criticism has put the Maroons on notice ahead of State of Origin II in Melbourne.

Hagan refused to return fire at Gallen but admitted old sparring partner Nate Myles might now want to "torment" the NSW leader on Wednesday night at the MCG.

Gallen launched an extraordinary attack on the Maroons on Tuesday, describing them as grubby and disrespectful.

"They were a little bit out of left field, I guess," Hagan said of Gallen, who missed game one due to injury.

"But I think that is part of what Paul Gallen brings to the team.

"It’s probably put us on notice as to what to expect.

"We know they are going to be really aggressive and we are going to have to counter that somehow."

Hagan did not rule out payback from prop Myles who infamously traded blows with Gallen in the 2013 Origin series.

"A bloke like Nate Myles probably missed Gal in the first game, from the point of view to have someone to torment for 80 minutes.

"It’s something to look forward to."

Hagan tried to bite his tongue when asked whether it was a "bit rich" that Gallen had called Queenslanders grubby.

"You could say that. But we are not about judging that," he said of Gallen’s own colourful on-field history.

"We are about getting the job done."

Hagan admitted being without halfback Cooper Cronk (knee) in game two was an issue but did not want to put too much pressure on replacement Daly Cherry-Evans.

Hagan said Cherry-Evans - who missed game one with a shoulder complaint - knew he would be targeted by a fired up NSW.

But Hagan believed Cherry-Evans was up for the challenge after emerging from a tumultuous period where he polarised the public by reneging on a Gold Coast deal and staying with Manly.

"He’s a pretty courageous player," Hagan said.

"He knows if he runs the ball, he will come under some attention.

"That’s part of why he is such a good player and why Manly were so desperate to keep him.

"You want to build a team around someone like that."

Hagan admitted Matt Scott (knee) was a concern on Monday but gave the prop the all-clear for game two.

Hagan also believed the Maroons would enjoy a home ground advantage at the MCG after being in camp in Melbourne since Tuesday last week.

NSW were accused by Queensland this week of not promoting the game after opting to remain in Coffs Harbour and not arriving in Melbourne until Sunday.

"The last couple of days have made us realise how much Queensland has that support," Hagan said.

"Tonight, I think we can maybe expect a little advantage."

displayImages.credit: Michael Dodge/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Queensland training
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Michael Dodge/Getty Images

headerImage.caption: Johnathan Thurston of the Maroons catches the ball during a Queensland Maroons State of Origin training session at Melbourne Cricket Ground. Photograph: Michael Dodge/Getty Images
headerImage.cleanCaption: Johnathan Thurston of the Maroons catches the ball during a Queensland Maroons State of Origin training session at Melbourne Cricket Ground.

snap.title: State of Origin: Queensland to fire up following 'left field' Gallen attack

cards.title: Snooker / Snooker, chess and bridge among sports to apply for 2020 Olympics inclusion
cards.rawTitle: Snooker, chess and bridge among sports to apply for 2020 Olympics inclusion

item.title: Snooker, chess and bridge among sports to apply for 2020 Olympics inclusion
item.trailText: Tug of war and baseball are also among a list of 26 sports to have applied for inclusion in the 2020 Games, before a shortlist is announced on 26 June
item.standFirst:
• Tug of war and baseball also among 26 sports to have applied for Tokyo Games
• Shortlist will be announced on 26 June before final decision next August
item.body:
Snooker, chess, bridge and tug of war are among the 26 sports to have applied for inclusion in the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo.

Baseball and softball have also applied, as has squash, after they were the sports to miss out when wrestling was reinstated by the International Olympic Committee in 2013 having initially been dropped for 2020.

Squash will be hoping to be included for the first time after missing out to golf and rugby sevens for the 2016 Games while baseball and softball, popular in Japan, is bidding to return having been dropped following Beijing 2008.

The Tokyo 2020 additional event programme panel will now narrow the 26 applicants down to a shortlist to be announced on 22 June, with a final decision due to be made by the IOC in August next year.

The decision will be made based on whether the applicant can “serve as a driving force to promote the Olympic movement and its values, with a focus on youth appeal” and “add value to the Games by engaging the Japanese population and new audiences worldwide, reflecting the Tokyo 2020 Games vision”.

The traditional Japanese sport of sumo has also lodged an application as have karate, American football, tenpin bowling, polo and orienteering.

Full list of federations to have applied for inclusion in the 2020 Olympic Games

World Air Sports Federation (FAI), International Federation of American Football (IFAF), World Baseball Softball Confederation (WBSC), World Confederation of Billiards Sports (WCBS), Bowls Sports World Confederation (CMSB), World Bowling (WB), World Bridge Federation (WBF), World Chess Federation (FIDE), World DanceSport Federation (WDSF), International Floorball Federation (IFF), World Flying Disc Federation (WFDF), World Karate Federation (WKF), International Korfball Federation (IKF), International Netball Federation (INF), International Orienteering Federation (IOF), Federation of International Polo (FIP), International Racquetball Federation (IRF), International Federation of Roller Sports (FIRS), International Federation of Sport Climbing (IFSC), World Squash Federation (WSF), International Sumo Federation (IFS), International Surfing Association (ISA), Tug of War International Federation (TWIF), World Underwater Federation (CMAS), International Waterski & Wakeboard Federation (IWWF), International Wushu Federation (IWUF).

displayImages.caption: Snooker has formally joined the race for inclusion in the 2020 Olympics in Tokyo. Photograph: Alamy

cards.title: US sports / Golden State Warriors win first NBA title in 40 years – as it happened
cards.rawTitle: Golden State Warriors win first NBA title in 40 years – as it happened

item.title: Golden State Warriors win first NBA title in 40 years – as it happened
item.trailText: Golden State Warriors beat Cleveland 105-97 to clinch their first NBA championship in 40 years
item.standFirst:
• Golden State Warriors beat Cleveland 105-97 in Game 6
  • Regular-season leaders win first NBA championship since 1975

displayImages.credit: Ezra Shaw/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Steph Curry celebrates Golden State’s win.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Ezra Shaw/Getty Images

bodyImages.caption: Draymond Green climbs all over Timofey Mozgov. Photograph: Paul Sancya/AP
bodyImages.altText: Draymond Green climbs all over Timofey Mozgov.
bodyImages.cleanCaption: Draymond Green climbs all over Timofey Mozgov.

bodyImages.caption: It’s tight! Photograph: Ezra Shaw/Getty Images
Steph Curry looks to the heavens. Photograph: Ezra Shaw/Getty Images
bodyImages.altText: Steph Curry looks to the heavens.
bodyImages.cleanCaption: Steph Curry looks to the heavens.

bodyImages.caption: Steph Curry goes up against JR Smith. Photograph: Ezra Shaw/Getty Images
bodyImages.altText: Steph Curry goes up against JR Smith.
bodyImages.cleanCaption: Steph Curry goes up against JR Smith.

blocks.body:
DJ will be here shortly. In the meantime, here are some thoughts on tonight’s game from Les Carpenter:

The Cleveland Cavaliers are tired now. The relentless zeal that pushed them to two early victories in the NBA finals has drained away. The series has grown long and the injuries to Kyrie Irving and Kevin Love have proven all but fatal to the title dreams that burned just a week ago. LeBron James and a whole lot of enthusiasm are no match for the speed and depth of Golden State.

Even with the series in Cleveland for Game 6 on Tuesday night, it feels like a last gasp for the Cavs. The way the Warriors raced past them in those final few minutes in Game 5 makes the result of this series seem a certainty.

And yet because this is the finals and Cleveland have James, there remains that shred of doubt. If James is going to have that career-defining moment of pure greatness he never had to have in his title with the Miami Heat, tonight would be the time to do it.

“One thing I’ve learned playing with LeBron for three years, you never count the man out,” his former team-mate Shane Battier said on a Monday conference call for the American Century Championship golf tournament. “If he scores 50 points, the Cavs will win. If he doesn’t I have the Golden State Warriors ending the series at six.”

Hello, ladies and gentlemen. After 5 1/2 months of regular season basketball and 2 months of the postseason, the 2014-2015 NBA season could come to an end this very night.

Of course, the big story is: CAN LEBRON WIN THE MVP ON A LOSING TEAM?!?

(Also, could the Golden State Warriors win a championship?)

The big controversy after Game 5 was the best player in the world saying that he’s the best player in the world:

We’ll see if there’s similar controversy after tonight’s game if the Warriors win the championship and then they say they won the championship.

J.R. Smith rolled into the arena again for Game 6.

Smith can’t afford to walk. He needs to conserve his energy to miss a lot of shots tonight.

Cavs head coach David Blatt was asked if Cleveland needs to be leading entering the 4th quarter to win. Here’ what he replied:

“I’ve been watching the horse races lately. It seems like the guy who was in front has been winning.”

There you go. Let’s never again question whether David Blatt is a basketball genius. Or if the media sometimes doesn’t ask great questions.
Cleveland fans are obviously desperate for a win tonight. But if it doesn’t happen, at least Cleveland will get to see a championship! That’s pretty exciting, right? Guys?

If the Warriors win, they have a shot at becoming a dynasty because of their youth.

On the other hand, the previous young teams -- the 2009 Lakers, the 2004 Pistons and the 2008 Celtics -- didn’t become dynasties. In fact, the only thing they’re trying to win year to year now is the draft lottery.
Wow. I guess no one will criticize LeBron James ever again.

Jerry West in 1969 was the last player to win Finals MVP on a losing team. I wonder if LeBron could one inspire a modern NBA logo as West did the current one.

If not the NBA logo, a silhouette of just LeBron could also serve as the logo of the Cleveland Cavaliers. In fact, it would be perfect.
If we get a Game 7, it will be because LeBron is Basketball God.

The Cavs just sent this out. One of the 3s in a 6-second clip was missed.

Oh, Cleveland.

blocks.title: Tip-off!
blocks.body: Cavs score first at 11:31 of the 1st quarter on a made free throw by Iman Shumpert. It’s 1-0. Okay ... let’s go to Game 7! We’re good here.
Cavs up 3-0 on a Mozgov layup, 10:35 left. Who are these non-LeBron Cavaliers who are scoring?

LeBron gets his first 2 points on a layup off of a Warriors turnover. 5-2 Cleveland with 9:30 left in the 1st quarter. Steph Curry is 0-for-1 in case you want to get in early on some Steph-Curry-is-bad-again action.

blocks.title: Cavaliers 7, Warriors 4. 8:05 left in the first.
blocks.body: Iguodala just took a charge as LeBron tried to plow through the lane. Iguodala is an insane person to step in front of James. Brave. But insane.
Remember that Cavaliers Vine I shared below that showed Shumpert missing a 3? He missed another one from the same spot. Only this time it was in the game. 8-8 tie, 5:33 left in the 1st quarter.
In a way, a floor perfectly captures Cleveland’s boring “skyline.”

Curry just hit his first 3, and the Warriors have their first lead, 11-8, and are on a 9-1 run.

Cleveland-area sad trombone players may get a lot of work tonight.

blocks.title: Warriors 15, Cavaliers 11. 3:37 left in the 1st.
blocks.body: J.R. Smith hits 1-of-2 from the line. He’s really feeling it!
The Warriors are hitting everything now and are up 23-15 with 1:42 left. If LeBron is going to do a 100-point game, he might want to get going.

Tristan Thompson is leading the Cavaliers with 6 points and is a perfect 3-for-3 from the field.

Who is going to tell LeBron that not only is he not the best player in the world, he’s not the best forward on the Cleveland Cavaliers?

Out of the timeout with Golden State up 23-15, Mozgov is on the bench. Cleveland is going smaller. Unfortunately for them, though, they’re small, medium and large lineups are all inferior to Golden State’s. Size doesn’t matter in this case, Cleveland.

blocks.title: End of the 1st quarter: Warriors 28, Cavaliers 15.
blocks.body: Curry bricked a 3 on one of Golden State’s final possessions, but it bounced right to Ezeli, who layed it in for an easy bucket. This it not looking like Cleveland’s night. Like most sports nights.
Golden State currently has a 13-point lead. And I’m going to guess their record in games in which they have a 13-point lead is also fairly solid.

blocks.title: Warriors 31, Cavaliers 21. 10:43 left in the half.
blocks.body: Cleveland got the lead down to 8 on a LeBron corner 3 with the shot clock expiring, but Leandro Barbosa answered right back with a 3. We almost had a game there. Knock it off, Barbosa!
This is a basketball truth as true as LeBron being the best player in the world.

TV timeout with the Warriors up 31-24 with 9:22 left in the half.

Timofey Mozgov is getting abused on both sides of the court. Putin will not stand for this.
Pitbull is currently playing in the arena. So don’t feel bad if Cleveland loses. They deserve it.
Mozgov just sent an Iguodala finger roll attempt flying volleyball spike-style ... and then seconds later fouled Iguodala. Cleveland had about 4 seconds of joy there.

blocks.title: Warriors 32, Cavaliers 26. 7:20 left in the half.
blocks.body:
Cleveland gets it to 6 points on a tough double and triple-pumping layup by James.

Never pass the ball again, LeBron. If the ball leaves your hands for the rest of the night, it should be heading towards the rim.

Hey, remember back when Matthew Dellavedova was a thing?

He has 0 points and a turnover tonight in 9 minutes.

Time for one of those “Where Are They Now?” features.
This quarter, Golden State is 1-for-10 and Cleveland is 3-for-10. We’re currently watching the 1st Round of the Sun Belt Conference Tournament.

blocks.title: Warriors 34, Cavaliers 29. 5:50 left in the half.
blocks.body: Shots were made on back-to-back possessions. It’s back to professional basketball! Alright!

Instead of shooting quality looks on the last two possessions, LeBron forced the ball to Timofey Mozgov. Timofey Mozgov. LeBron is in an elimination game and he’s looking to get the ball to Timofey Mozgov.

If this is LeBron’s idea, he needs to be fired as head coach.

ANDREW BOGUT IS YOUR HERO NOW.

Oh, right. He doesn’t play anymore. Hmmm.

Warriors 39, Cavaliers 31. 4:15 left in the half.

LeBron just threw it into Mozgov again. It didn’t end well.

This game will end in the same way if he keeps doing this.
Shumpert just picked up another foul trying to chase Steph Curry around a screen. When Shumpert comes in from his deck, he probably just goes right through the screen door, Kool-Aid Man style.

blocks.title: Warriors 39, Cavaliers 33. 3:37 left in the half.
blocks.body: It’s a media timeout. Probably so the media can begin writing their LeBron-is-no-Jordan pieces. It’s an original idea.
He’s looking for a new basketball best friend to replace Dennis Rodman.

LeBron just got his first free throws of the night ... and missed them both. He’s making this hard on himself. As though playing in Cleveland isn’t making it hard enough already.

40-33. 3:23 left in the half.

Warriors 43, Cavaliers 35. 2:10 left in the half.

LeBron and Curry just made turnovers. This is an ugly game. If this was the first game you watched all season, you wouldn’t be impressed. But it would be weird if this was the first game you watched all season. It would be even weirder if you were watching your first game and following this liveblog.

blocks.title: Halftime: Warriors 45, Cavaliers 43.
blocks.body:
After trailing by 13 at the end of the 1st quarter, the Cavs made a late run in the 2nd quarter to get within two. Tristan Thompson followed up a LeBron miss before the buzzer with a huge put-back dunk.

Thompson has 11 and 7 at the half. LeBron has 15 and 8. So LeBron remains the best player in the world. FOR NOW.

Cavs had 13 turnovers in the 1st half. BAD!

Cavs out-rebounded Golden State, 29-16. GOOD!

Cavs shot 17 more FTs in the 1st half than the Warriors. GOOD!

Cavs shot only 13-for-21 from the line. BAD!

My prediction for the 2nd half: I have no idea.
Not a bad end to the half.
At the half, Klay Thompson has 2 points.

ABC’s halftime crew felt LeBron was conserving energy in the first half.

It could be that, it could be that he’s tired from being the whole team all playoffs.

blocks.title: Cleveland 47, Warriors 45. 10:11 left in the half.
blocks.body: Cleveland’s early buckets are by Mozgov and Thompson. At least one Thompson is bothering to play this game.

Warriors 53, Cavaliers 47. 8:13 left in the 3rd.

Golden State is on a 7-0 run after falling behind. Klay Thompson still has 2 points. LeBron is still apparently conserving energy.
I need a nap, I need a nap, tell the world that I need a nap ...

Warriors 56, Cavaliers 51. 6:50 left in the 3rd.

LeBron has taken it to the hoop on back-to-back possessions. Is it finally starting?

blocks.title: Klay Thompson has 4 fouls with 6:15 left in the third.
blocks.body: He also has two points. Soooooooo is it bad for Golden State if he fouls out?

blocks.title: Warriors 61, Cavaliers 51. 5:11 left in the 3rd.
blocks.body: Warriors are on a 16-4 run, forcing Cleveland to call timeout. Iguodala now has 17 points and is 7-for-14 from the floor. I wonder what kind of defense Iguodala could play on a player the caliber of Iguodala.

Great drive by Shaun Livingston gives Golden State a 63-53 lead with 4:30 left.

I still wince every time Livingston jumps and cuts on the court, terrified his leg will snap off again.
Remember that Cleveland’s best shot to win -- outside of LeBron scoring 100 -- is to play great defense.

blocks.title: Warriors 69, Cavaliers 55. 3:05 left in the 3rd.
blocks.body: Ezeli stuffs back a Curry missed three, gets fouled and hits the free throw. All of Cleveland’s hard work coming back in the 2nd quarter has been erased. But effort is its own reward, right?

The clips that the broadcast shares of coaches in the huddle doesn’t do the coaches any favors. They can’t air strategy stuff, so they just show motivational cliches. It makes the average viewer think NBA coaches are guys paid millions of dollars to yell lines from cat posters.

blocks.title: Warriors 73, Cavaliers 58. Less than a minute left in the 3rd.
blocks.body: From earlier in the liveblog, you’ll recall the Warriors haven’t lost all season when leading by 15. You can shut the game off, if you’d like ... BUT DON’T CLOSE YOUR BROWSER!

blocks.title: End of the 3rd: Warriors 73, Cavaliers 61.
blocks.body:
Mozgov has 11 and 10 and 4 blocks.

Tristan Thompson has 13 and 12.

I don’t want to be that guy, but I’m about to be that guy: LeBron James isn’t doing enough for the Cavaliers to win.
The Cavaliers are going to play out the final 12 minutes for the liveblog. They’re professionals.
I’m happy to do any and everything I can. I’m like Shawn Marion that way. We’re also both making an equal impact on the Finals.

A team needing to make a huge comeback to stay alive in the NBA Finals has started J.R. Smith in the 4th quarter.

Just wanted to note this amazing moment in basketball history.

Warriors 75, Cavaliers 62. 11:00 minutes left.

Cleveland has now missed 11 free throws. If they made all of their free throws, they’d be ... losing still.

blocks.title: Warriors 75, Cavaliers 68. 10:13 left.
blocks.body: Mozgov hits two FTs and then LeBron gets a steal and a dunk. They’re within 7 points. This game shall continue to be acceptable entertainment for the remainder of the evening.
My god ... the NBA MVP, Steph Curry, hit a 3 to give the Warriors a 10-point lead, so J.R. Smith -- not the MVP -- decided he’d counter with an out-of-control drive that failed miserably.

blocks.title: Warriors 86, Cavaliers 75. 7:15 left.
blocks.body:
Another 3 by Steph Curry.

Steph’s mom and daughter are not in the crowd. That can’t help the TV ratings.

Klay Thompson finally contributed by hitting a wide open 3. The lead is now 14.

We are 6+ minutes away from the City of Oakland winning a sports title. The last time that happened, the Oakland A’s in 1989, there was not a liveblog of the festivities.
This stat is both amazing and cruel:

Kelly Olynyk should probably avoid the ol’ Twitter mentions tonight.

It’s ugly in there.
Perkins, Shawn Marion, Mike Miller. Is it really much worse than what Cleveland normally runs out there with LeBron? Really? Think about your answer. Really?

Oh, yeah ... I should probably update you on the score: 94-79, 4:37 left.

It’s that quiet, foregone conclusion point of the game where the in-arena announcer is the loudest noise.

Klay Thompson just fouled out. This would potentially be important if the game was closer than 13 points with only a few minutes left. Hey, we should pretend it IS important just to convince ourselves there’s still a chance this game gets close.

Down 11 with 3:40 left, J.R. Smith decide to try to post up Steph Curry, but he stumbled and traveled.

This has been your J.R. Smith is a Basketball Disaster update.

blocks.title: Warriors 98, Cavaliers 85. 1:50 left.
blocks.body:
LeBron and friends just stood there and watched Curry go in for an uncontested layup. So the game is officially over now. All that’s left is further Cleveland humiliation.

Oh ... and I was wrong. Steph Curry’s mom is in attendance. I hope by false report earlier didn’t destroy worldwide TV ratings.
98-89. Only 1:01 to go and Cleveland will be out of its misery. Until the next Indians game and then when Browns season starts and then next Cavaliers season and then the Indians again and then ...

100-92, 55 seconds left. Warriors call timeout.

Respectable final score alert! Respectable final score alert!
The public address guy is desperately trying to get the crowd to make noise. They’re not obliging. It’s pretty depressing.

Now it’s 100-94 with 37.2 left. Steph Curry to the line.

This is one scraptastic batch of Cavaliers.

HAAAAAAAAAAAhahahahahahaha. J.R. Smith just put up a prayer 3 ... and made it. 101-97 with 29.1 left.

J.R. Smith: never not entertaining.
That should do it. Warriors 104-97 with 10.6 left.

blocks.title: FINAL SCORE: Warriors 105, Cavaliers 97.
blocks.body:
Congratulations to the Warriors. Congratulations to Oakland.

Celebrate responsibly.

Cleveland: sorrow responsibly.

The Warriors could easily be back next year. But it’s hard to get out of the West.

The Cavaliers are, barring an injury to LeBron James, a lock to be back. The guy just took a collection of rejects to a close, 4-2 loss in the Finals to the NBA team with the best record.

But now I’m the guy talking about next year when this year just ended. Don’t be that guy. He’s annoying.

Congratulations to the Warriors.

Andre Iguodala was named NBA Finals MVP, not LeBron.

Guess how the remaining Cleveland fans reacted?

If you guessed that they booed, you are a winner! Just like the Warriors!

That’s it from me – thanks so much for joing me in these finals. And congratulations to the Warriors. I’ll leave you with Daniel McGraw’s game report. Good night!

Related: Golden State Warriors crowned NBA champions after easing past tired Cavs

keyEvents.body:
DJ will be here shortly. In the meantime, here are some thoughts on tonight’s game from Les Carpenter:

The Cleveland Cavaliers are tired now. The relentless zeal that pushed them to two early victories in the NBA finals has drained away. The series has grown long and the injuries to Kyrie Irving and Kevin Love have proven all but fatal to the title dreams that burned just a week ago. LeBron James and a whole lot of enthusiasm are no match for the speed and depth of Golden State.

Even with the series in Cleveland for Game 6 on Tuesday night, it feels like a last gasp for the Cavs. The way the Warriors raced past them in those final few minutes in Game 5 makes the result of this series seem a certainty.

And yet because this is the finals and Cleveland have James, there remains that shred of doubt. If James is going to have that career-defining moment of pure greatness he never had to have in his title with the Miami Heat, tonight would be the time to do it.

“One thing I’ve learned playing with LeBron for three years, you never count the man out,” his former team-mate Shane Battier said on a Monday conference call for the American Century Championship golf tournament. “If he scores 50 points, the Cavs will win. If he doesn’t I have the Golden State Warriors ending the series at six.”

keyEvents.title: Tip-off!
keyEvents.body: Cavs score first at 11:31 of the 1st quarter on a made free throw by Iman Shumpert. It’s 1-0. Okay ... let’s go to Game 7! We’re good here.

keyEvents.title: Cavaliers 7, Warriors 4. 8:05 left in the first.
keyEvents.body: Iguodala just took a charge as LeBron tried to plow through the lane. Iguodala is an insane person to step in front of James. Brave. But insane.

keyEvents.title: Warriors 15, Cavaliers 11. 3:37 left in the 1st.
keyEvents.body: J.R. Smith hits 1-of-2 from the line. He’s really feeling it!

keyEvents.title: End of the 1st quarter: Warriors 28, Cavaliers 15.
keyEvents.body: Curry bricked a 3 on one of Golden State’s final possessions, but it bounced right to Ezeli, who layed it in for an easy bucket. This it not looking like Cleveland’s night. Like most sports nights.

keyEvents.title: Warriors 31, Cavaliers 21. 10:43 left in the half.
keyEvents.body: Cleveland got the lead down to 8 on a LeBron corner 3 with the shot clock expiring, but Leandro Barbosa answered right back with a 3. We almost had a game there. Knock it off, Barbosa!

keyEvents.title: Warriors 32, Cavaliers 26. 7:20 left in the half.
keyEvents.body:
Cleveland gets it to 6 points on a tough double and triple-pumping layup by James.

Never pass the ball again, LeBron. If the ball leaves your hands for the rest of the night, it should be heading towards the rim.

keyEvents.title: Warriors 34, Cavaliers 29. 5:50 left in the half.
keyEvents.body: Shots were made on back-to-back possessions. It’s back to professional basketball! Alright!

keyEvents.title: Warriors 39, Cavaliers 33. 3:37 left in the half.
keyEvents.body: It’s a media timeout. Probably so the media can begin writing their LeBron-is-no-Jordan pieces. It’s an original idea.

keyEvents.title: Halftime: Warriors 45, Cavaliers 43.
keyEvents.body:
After trailing by 13 at the end of the 1st quarter, the Cavs made a late run in the 2nd quarter to get within two. Tristan Thompson followed up a LeBron miss before the buzzer with a huge put-back dunk.

Thompson has 11 and 7 at the half. LeBron has 15 and 8. So LeBron remains the best player in the world. FOR NOW.

keyEvents.title: Cleveland 47, Warriors 45. 10:11 left in the half.
keyEvents.body: Cleveland’s early buckets are by Mozgov and Thompson. At least one Thompson is bothering to play this game.

keyEvents.title: Klay Thompson has 4 fouls with 6:15 left in the third.
keyEvents.body: He also has two points. Soooooooo is it bad for Golden State if he fouls out?

keyEvents.title: Warriors 61, Cavaliers 51. 5:11 left in the 3rd.
keyEvents.body: Warriors are on a 16-4 run, forcing Cleveland to call timeout. Iguodala now has 17 points and is 7-for-14 from the floor. I wonder what kind of defense Iguodala could play on a player the caliber of Iguodala.

keyEvents.title: Warriors 69, Cavaliers 55. 3:05 left in the 3rd.
keyEvents.body: Ezeli stuffs back a Curry missed three, gets fouled and hits the free throw. All of Cleveland’s hard work coming back in the 2nd quarter has been erased. But effort is its own reward, right?

keyEvents.title: Warriors 73, Cavaliers 58. Less than a minute left in the 3rd.
keyEvents.body: From earlier in the liveblog, you’ll recall the Warriors haven’t lost all season when leading by 15. You can shut the game off, if you’d like ... BUT DON’T CLOSE YOUR BROWSER!

keyEvents.title: End of the 3rd: Warriors 73, Cavaliers 61.
keyEvents.body:
Mozgov has 11 and 10 and 4 blocks.

Tristan Thompson has 13 and 12.

I don’t want to be that guy, but I’m about to be that guy: LeBron James isn’t doing enough for the Cavaliers to win.

keyEvents.title: Warriors 75, Cavaliers 68. 10:13 left.
keyEvents.body: Mozgov hits two FTs and then LeBron gets a steal and a dunk. They’re within 7 points. This game shall continue to be acceptable entertainment for the remainder of the evening.

keyEvents.title: Warriors 86, Cavaliers 75. 7:15 left.
keyEvents.body:
Another 3 by Steph Curry.

Steph’s mom and daughter are not in the crowd. That can’t help the TV ratings.

keyEvents.title: Warriors 98, Cavaliers 85. 1:50 left.
keyEvents.body:
LeBron and friends just stood there and watched Curry go in for an uncontested layup. So the game is officially over now. All that’s left is further Cleveland humiliation.

Oh ... and I was wrong. Steph Curry’s mom is in attendance. I hope by false report earlier didn’t destroy worldwide TV ratings.

keyEvents.title: FINAL SCORE: Warriors 105, Cavaliers 97.
keyEvents.body:
Congratulations to the Warriors. Congratulations to Oakland.

Celebrate responsibly.

Cleveland: sorrow responsibly.

stillImage.caption: OAKLAND, CA - JUNE 16:  Golden State Warriors fans celebrate their team's 2015 NBA Finals win Photograph: Justin Sullivan/Getty Images North America
stillImage.altText: Raucous Golden State Warriors Fans Celebrate NBA Finals Victory
stillImage.cleanCaption: OAKLAND, CA - JUNE 16:  Golden State Warriors fans celebrate their team's 2015 NBA Finals win Photograph: Justin Sullivan/Getty Images North America

snap.title: Golden State Warriors win first NBA title in 40 years – as it happened

image.credit: Ezra Shaw/Getty Images
image.altText: Steph Curry celebrates Golden State’s win.
image.cleanCredit: Photograph: Ezra Shaw/Getty Images

cards.title: Australia sport / Socceroos fans 'manhandled' at qualifier mars Kyrgyzstan experience
cards.rawTitle: Socceroos fans 'manhandled' at qualifier mars Kyrgyzstan experience

item.title: Socceroos fans 'manhandled' at qualifier mars Kyrgyzstan experience
item.trailText: While the experience in and around Bishkek has been genial, problems inside the stadium has ruined some Socceroos fans’ World Cup experience
item.standFirst: While the experience in and around Bishkek has been genial, problems inside the stadium has ruined some Socceroos fans’ World Cup experience
item.body:
Young children were physically intimidated and a dozen Australians refused entry at yesterday’s World Cup qualifier match in Kyrgyzstan, an Australian supporter has told The Guardian.

Pablo Bateson is one of the organisers of the Australian football team’s travelling supporters’ group. He says what happened getting into yesterday’s match was the worst experience he has had in years of following the team around the world.

“There were really young kids - six or seven year olds with their parents - being pushed around,” he says. “The way some of the fans were manhandled by over-enthusiastic home supporters, police, security, it was very tense and it just about got out of hand.”

He says there was no provision for Australian fans to enter the ground safely, there was a stand-off style situation with the police as they tried to enter and the group was split in two.

“We were trying to convince them we have tickets, but it took an awful lot. Then when they accepted there was a right for entry, there were local fans and some other really strange people trying to prevent us from getting around the barrier and into the area the police were trying to channel us into.”

Security was heavy-handed getting into the venue, and organisation was chaotic. Some people had their bags searched seven times, with police continually stopping supporters as they made their way from the entrance to their seats.

Around a dozen supporters - some who had travelled from Melbourne - were refused entry on the grounds that the match was a sell-out, Bateson says. They all held valid tickets. One woman was even refused re-entry after going outside to use the stadium’s portable toilets.

The stadium’s official capacity is 18,000 but many people say the number in attendance was far greater. Home fans were seen jumping the fences to get in, and dozens of people scaled the ground’s light towers - and to quite dizzying heights - to watch the match.

Bateson says several hundred home supporters were allowed to rush into the away section during the first half, despite concerns it was about to get out of hand. “You just don’t do that,” he says. “I’ve never had that before at an away game.” The pleas of expats - done in the local language - were ignored.

Australian parents with children at the game left at half-time due to safety concerns. “You expect the unexpected ... but I think in the end it was all too much.”

After the game, the Australian team manager told the travelling fans to stay in their section while the crowds dispersed, as there was “a lot of nasty stuff going on outside...it was bordering on riotous”. However, Bateson says local authorities insisted the Socceroo fans clear their bay and leave the stadium promptly.

During the evening, a large group of demonstrators protesting against the country’s leader - who was in attendance - came close to getting through or over the stadiums’ fences, but dispersed once riot police arrived at the scene. The country experienced coups in 2005 and 2010.

Bateson - who was once on a supporters’ bus that was stoned by home fans in Jordan - says there was a breakdown in command and poor communication by those in charge. He says the behaviour at the stadium was in complete contrast to the atmosphere he otherwise felt in the capital of Bishkek, and the warm gestures of support the group received on the way to the ground.

“I’m not blaming the local authorities, because (having a team as big as Australia come here) is quite a unique situation, so we have to balance it with that, (but) I just hope they learn from this for the future.”

Guardian Australia is seeking comment from local authorities.

displayImages.credit: Warren Little/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Australia v Kyrgyzstan
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Warren Little/Getty Images

headerImage.caption: Action during the 2018 FIFA World Cup Qualifier match between Kyrgyzstan and the Socceroos at Dolen Omurzakov Stadium. Photograph: Warren Little/Getty Images
headerImage.cleanCaption: Action during the 2018 FIFA World Cup Qualifier match between Kyrgyzstan and the Socceroos at Dolen Omurzakov Stadium.

snap.title: Socceroos fans 'manhandled' at qualifier mars Kyrgyzstan experience | Jack Kerr

cards.title: Olympic Games 2016 / USA men beat Canada to join women in Rio Olympic Games rugby sevens
cards.rawTitle: USA men beat Canada to join women in Rio Olympic Games rugby sevens

item.title: USA men beat Canada to join women in Rio Olympic Games rugby sevens
item.trailText: Men beat North American rivals 21-5 to win Nacra Sevens title while Canadians must now qualify from world repechage event next year
item.standFirst:
• Men beat North American rivals 21-5 to win Nacra Sevens title
  • Canadians must now qualify from world repechage event next year
item.body:
The USA men’s and women’s sevens teams booked their places at the Rio Olympic Games on Sunday, by winning their respective titles at the Nacra Sevens in Cary, North Carolina.

Both teams strolled through the qualifying matches against exponentially weaker opposition from the Caribbean and Central America, and Ric Suggitt’s women completed their task by crushing Mexico 88-0 in the final.

Mike Friday’s men, who last month won their first HSBC Sevens World Series title in London, were given a tougher task at WakeMed Soccer Park, facing keen rivals Canada in the decider.

First-half tries from Perry Baker, Danny Barrett and Maka Unufe, all converted by captain Madison Hughes, established a 21-0 lead at the break in the 20-minute final. Folau Niua was shown a yellow card shortly before the turnaround, but Mike Friday’s team survived his absence, showing strong resolve in defence.

Harry Jones scored a second-half try for Canada to close the gap, although Nathan Hirayama sent the conversion off the post. The USA’s Saracens back Chris Wyles, brought into the squad for the tournament as its only member not training full time at the Olympic centre in California, was shown another yellow card as the clock ran down. But it was too late for Canada to come back.

Canada, who fielded a strong squad for Nacra, must now attempt to qualify for Rio – at which rugby, albeit in its shortened form, will return to the Games for the first time since 1924 – at a global repechage event to be staged next year.

Each Olympic tournament will feature 12 teams. In the men’s game, the US join the top four World Series finishers – Fiji, South Africa, New Zealand and England (who booked a spot in Rio for Great Britain) – plus hosts Brazil and South American qualifiers Argentina in confirming their place at the Games. European qualifying continues this month, with France the clear favourites to progress.

Canada’s women had already qualified for Rio through the World Series, with New Zealand, Australia and England. Those teams and Brazil have now been joined by the US and Colombia in the draw for the Olympic event.

Asia, Africa and Oceania will decide their automatic qualifiers in tournaments held later this year.

The USA are the reigning Olympic rugby champions, having won 15-a-side gold in Paris 91 years ago. They also won gold in Antwerp in 1920.

displayImages.credit: Christopher Lee/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Danny Barrett, Madison Hughes
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Christopher Lee/Getty Images

headerImage.caption: Danny Barrett and Madison Hughes, shown here celebrating in London last month, were among the points scorers in Cary, North Carolina. Photograph: Christopher Lee/Getty Images
headerImage.cleanCaption: Danny Barrett and Madison Hughes, shown here celebrating in London last month, were among the points scorers in Cary, North Carolina.

snap.title: USA men beat Canada to join women in Rio Olympic Games rugby sevens

image.credit: Christopher Lee/Getty Images
image.altText: Danny Barrett, Madison Hughes
image.cleanCredit: Photograph: Christopher Lee/Getty Images

cards.title: Sailing / Volvo Ocean Race: stage eight

item.title: Volvo Ocean Race: stage eight
item.trailText: The best pictures from the eighth leg of the 2014-15 Volvo Ocean Race, from Lisbon in Portugal to Lorient in France.
item.standFirst:
The best pictures from the eighth leg of the 2014-15 Volvo Ocean Race, from Lisbon in Portugal to Lorient in France. The race covers 39,379 nautical miles and will visit 11 ports in 11 countries over nine months.
• More of the best images from the Volvo Ocean Race so far
